metadata.case_name: Harnam Singh v. State of Himachal Pradesh

facts.text: In September 1967, Harnam Singh was working as a Patwari in Halqa Pali.
On 19th September 1967, Nitya Nand asked Harnam Singh for copies of revenue record; Harnam Singh demanded hush-money of Rs. 30.
On 20th September 1967, Nitya Nand borrowed Rs. 30 from friend Chet Ram and lodged complaint with Anti-Corruption Department.

Sub Inspector Kewal Ram obtained permission from Mandi Magistrate to investigate and laid trap; raiding party went to Harnam Singh's office where Nitya Nand allegedly gave marked currency notes of Rs. 30 to Harnam Singh.
Defence: Rs. 30 not found from Harnam Singh's person but planted by Nitya Nand in residential room.

Special Judge Mandi, Kulu and Lahaul Spiti Districts convicted Harnam Singh under section 5(1)(d) read with section 5(2) of Prevention of Corruption Act and section 161 IPC; sentenced to RI for 2 years and fine Rs. 300.
Delhi High Court Himachal Bench confirmed conviction but reduced substantive sentence to 1 year RI; judgment dated 18th December 1969/7th January 1970.
Harnam Singh died during pendency of appeal in Supreme Court; by order dated 26 February 1972, his widow substituted as legal representative.

Prosecution witnesses: Nitya Nand (complainant), Kewal Ram (IO), Jai Ram (HC), Panchas Sital Prasad and Lok Bandhu (turned hostile). High Court found PW1, Kewal Ram, Jai Ram partisan; investigation not commendable.

Kewal Ram wrote complaint, obtained Magistrate permission by misleading (no DSP available, hid Inspector Amar Singh in charge); Panchnamas lack time/place; no anthracene powder; witnesses couldn't see/hear; Panchas known to complainant; Jai Ram got affidavit from Sital Prasad; discrepancy on recovery from jacket or shirt pocket.
Accused examined himself; evidence preferred over prosecution.

legal_issues.text: Whether the appeal abates on death of appellant sentenced to composite sentence of imprisonment and fine, under section 431 CrPC 1898, and whether widow can continue appeal.
Whether conviction sustainable on prosecution evidence, given partisan witnesses, hostile panchas, investigation lapses, and violation of s5A Prevention of Corruption Act.

petitioner_arguments.text: Section 431 CrPC 1898 has no application to appeals by special leave under Article 136; governed by justice/equity; even if applies, since sentenced to fine, appeal does not abate; if conviction bad, fine unsustainable so conviction must go.
Violation of s5A PC Act caused prejudice; evidence unreliable: planted money, investigation lapses.

respondent_arguments.text: Substantive imprisonment sentence ended with death, appeal abates as to it; composite sentence, appeal abates as to fine too; at best set aside fine, but conviction/substantive sentence stand.

court_reasoning.text: S431 CrPC not apply to Art 136 appeals but uniformity requires same principles; appeals vs acquittal abate on accused death; conviction appeals abate on appellant death except from sentence of fine; composite sentence appeal is 'from sentence of fine' as fine affects estate; validity of fine involves conviction validity; if conviction bad, set aside all.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Appeal from composite sentence does not abate fully; widow entitled to continue.

court_reasoning.text: Prosecution evidence unreliable: partisan witnesses, hostile panchas no corroboration, investigation lapses (Kewal Ram misled Magistrate, no disclosure of superior, no time/place in panchnamas, no anthracene, poor vantage, prior acquaintance, affidavit pressure, recovery discrepancy); accused evidence preferred; s5A violation caused prejudice but unnecessary as merits fail.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Evidence wholly unworthy of acceptance; gross injustice.

holdings.text: Appeal by legal representative maintainable despite death as it is from sentence of fine (even composite); if conviction invalid, set aside conviction and all sentences.

precedents_cited.case_name: Gondada Gajapathy Rao v. State of Andhra Pradesh
precedents_cited.relevance: No fine sentence; LRs interest remote (service arrears), unlike direct fine liability on estate.
Held composite appeal abates as to imprisonment but continues as to fine; bisection unjust.

precedents_cited.case_name: V. Govindrajalu Ors. v. State of Mysore
precedents_cited.relevance: Assumed partial abatement in composite sentence without discussion.

statutes_cited.name: Prevention of Corruption Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Conviction under 5(1)(d) r/w 5(2); s5A violated by unauthorised investigation causing prejudice.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Conviction u/s 161; s70 on fine levy post-death.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898
statutes_cited.relevance: Abatement rules; exception for fine appeals; sentence follows conviction.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973
statutes_cited.relevance: Amends abatement for near relatives in conviction appeals.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Special leave appeals not strictly under CrPC Ch XXXI but apply same abatement principles.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; order of conviction, substantive sentence and sentence of fine set aside.
outcome.relief_granted: Acquittal by setting aside conviction and sentences

key_quotes.text: "Every appeal under this Chapter except an appeal from a sentence of fine shall finally abate on the death of the appellant."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key statutory language interpreted to save composite sentence appeals.

key_quotes.text: "The sentence of fine becomes illegal if the conviction is wrong. If the conviction is wrong, no sentence at all can be imposed on the accused."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains why conviction must fall if challenged via fine appeal.

key_quotes.text: "We find it extremely difficult to appreciate how the evidence of these hostile witnesses could corroborate the evidence of the partisan witnesses."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects High Court reliance on unreliable evidence.

key_quotes.text: "The evidence on which the conviction is based is wholly unworthy of acceptance."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core finding overturning conviction on merits.
